messageBody:
On 2002-07-03 at 14:53 Mark Meyers wrote:

>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: J. B. Rainsberger
>...
>> >> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
>> >...
>> >> >...
>...
>>
>> Do you have experience to back up this statement? I started learning
>> Smalltalk using a combination of:
>>
>> * Well-named classes
>> * A primer on the syntax
>> * SUnit
>>
>Agreed, I learned about Smalltalk whitout the benefit of SUnit.

Poor man.

>When starting with java, I tried to do it the same way (VisualAge
offers
>similar funcionality in the scrapbook).

I like the scrapbook in VAJ. Always did.

>Switching to forte, I had a test class with a main method, where I
typed
>some code to see what it did.
>I believe that's a very common way to explore any programming
language...

An interpreter is best: I liked that when a first started with Ruby; I
liked that with Smalltalk and I've seen one or two in Java. I think
that interpreters are the perfect way to take the very first steps with
a language. Next is writing tests.

>Now I put all that exploring code in testcases, so I can use them as
>documentation later.

Excellent. EVERYONE PAY ATTENTION.

>Wouldn't want to start counting how often I "explored"
>Class.isAssignableFrom(Class) - amongst others. Whenever I read the
>javadoc:
>
> "Determines if the class or interface represented by this Class
object
>is
>either the same as,
> or is a superclass or
> superinterface of, the class or interface represented by
> the specified Class parameter."

Would this not be clearer?

Determines whether the object 'that' can be assigned to an object
whose type is the current Class object.

This is a special case of writing a comment that describes the
implementation, rather than explains the intent. A stupid comment, in
other words.

>I start panicking. The method name does not help either
>(Class.isSuperTypeOf(Class) would be clearer).

I think isAssignableFrom() is a fine name, and it even works without
documentation:

assertTrue( this.getClass().isAssignableFrom(that) );

Clear enough for me. Even better would be:

assertTrue( this.canBeAssignedTo(thatClass) );

The method should just be on Object, or mixed in from
RuntimeTypeInformation. Shame there are no mixins in Java...

> public void testIsAssignableFrom(){
> assertTrue(Number.class.isAssignableFrom(Integer.class));
> }
>
>is much clearer to me, poor programmer.
>Meaning: "an instance of class Integer can be assigned to a variable
of
>type
>Number".

Perfect.

>or "Number is a super class of Integer".

Less perfect; the above is more to the point. Number could, after all,
be an interface that Integer implements.

>BTW, JB, is this what you call learning tests ?

Yes, although I saw Kent first use the term in his Test-Driven
Development book. Thanks, Kent.
